body:
Thanks @mloning ! 

I'll start working on 02_classification.

Basically I plan to "preserve" the code from the tutorial notebooks and only take relevant code snippets & explanatory text from the code breakfast notebooks.

issue.title: Replace gunpoint dataset in tutorials, added OSULeaf dataset

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the extension guidelines: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs

Issue #294 as part of PyData Amsterdam 2020

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
- Replace gunpoint dataset in tutorials 02_classification_univariate, feature_extraction_with_tsfresh, loading_data, rocket, shapelet_transform
- Added OSULeaf dataset to replace gunpoint dataset in shapelet transform tutorial.
- Replaced 01_forecasting tutorial with the same tutorial from PyData Amsterdam code breakfast.
- Removed gunpoint dataset

Notes:
- img folder has also be updated with figures used in the tutorials.
- Added the `random_state` parameter to `train_test_split` for reproducibility.

#### Any other comments?
This is my first PR for sktime and my 3rd time contributing to an open source project! Thanks for having me and for being open to making these changes to the tutorials.

body: 03_classification doesn't seem to use the gunpoint dataset. Now working on feature_extraction_with_tsfresh.
Oh yes, my bad, that's on multivariate data only!

@mloning Would it be okay to also replace references to GunPoint in the loading_data notebook? This would involve adding new arff and tsv files, which I found for the ArrowHead dataset.

A related question would be, would there be any use for the GunPoint dataset after making all these replacements? If it's essentially obsolete then may be it should removed from the library altogether?

@marielledado Yes, feel free to replace it there as well. 

The only notebook where we use the gun point data set is to explain shapelets based on the published paper and diagram. My impression is that removing it there takes away of the intuition what the algorithm does. Any ideas?

@mloning I did some digging around and found [a paper that used shapelets on a reptile skull dataset](https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/c505/10c8ccf2a24e98db1ca3b1d34e41a759d286.pdf). The figures are pretty illustrative, but I couldn't find a dataset for it unfortunately. I suppose it would be good for the sample dataset and the illustrations to be the same in the tutorial.

I suppose we could leave the gunpoint in the shapelet notebook for now, then maybe I can email the authors to ask if they can provide the reptile skull dataset?
@mloning Nice, I'll give the leaf data set a go.
#300 gives some hints on how to add a new data set
